question.title: Swing: How to center a button near the bottom of a JFrame without using setBounds()?
question.body:
I’m working on a Java Swing application and would like to place a button so that it is horizontally centered and vertically positioned near the bottom of the window — similar to how a typical “Submit” button is placed in many UIs. I do not want it to be exactly at the bottom edge, but rather visually centered in the lower portion of the window.

At the moment, I’m using a null layout and manually positioning the button using setBounds().

This works, but it is hardcoded and inflexible. As soon as the window size changes, the layout no longer looks right. I’ve looked into layout managers like BorderLayout, BoxLayout, and GridBagLayout, but none of them seem to provide an easy way to achieve this kind of positioning — or at least I haven’t found a clean solution.

Is there a more flexible and layout-manager-based approach to achieve this type of positioning, without relying on absolute values?

import javax.swing.JFrame;
import javax.swing.JButton;

public class Main {

    public Main() {
        
        JFrame frame = new JFrame("Unit Converter");
        frame.setSize(800, 300);
        frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
        frame.setLayout(null);
        
        JButton convertButton = new JButton("Convert");
        convertButton.setBounds(((800 - 250) / 2), 200, 250, 50);
        
        frame.add(convertButton);
        
        frame.setVisible(true);
    }
    
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        
        new Main();
        
    }

}

I want it to look like this:

answers.body:
As soon as the window size changes, the layout no longer looks right.

And that's one of the reasons to use a layout manager.

I’ve looked into layout managers like BorderLayout, BoxLayout, and GridBagLayout, but none of them seem to provide an easy way to achieve this kind of positioning

All of those provide ways to achieve that layout.

  • with BorderLayout, you could get where you want by putting the "Convert" button south, with various options for where the other controls go.

  • With BoxLayout, you might create a vertical Box, with a nested horizontal Box above for the top two controls, and the "Convert" button below.

  • With GridBagLayout you can do almost anything, and this particular layout wouldn't be too involved. GidBagLayout would probably be overkill here, and a solution based on it would be more complex than one based on BorderLayout or BoxLayout.

Overall, you would probably benefit from reading the chapter of the Layout chapter of the Swing Tutorial.

Note also that for JFrame, just like for any other lightweight component, you should be adding components the the frame's content pane, not directly to the frame itself.

As you seem to have realized, you should never do either of these things:

frame.setLayout(null);
convertButton.setBounds(((800 - 250) / 2), 200, 250, 50);

One problem is that the position and size that look good on your computer, won’t look right on some other computers. A “12 point font” means each line of text is ¹²⁄₇₂ inches high. How many pixels that requires depends on the size of dot pitch of the monitor, and Windows further complicates that with its desktop scaling.

The other problem, as you’ve discovered, is that an absolute position and size can’t adapt to a changing window size.

Layout managers are designed to solve all of that. For that reason, applications should always use them and should never ever do setLayout(null).

Your layout is fairly simple, so you can make do with something short:

import java.text.NumberFormat;

import java.awt.EventQueue;
import java.awt.BorderLayout;

import javax.swing.JButton;
import javax.swing.JComboBox;
import javax.swing.JFormattedTextField;
import javax.swing.JPanel;
import javax.swing.JFrame;
import javax.swing.text.NumberFormatter;

public class UnitConverter {
    public enum Units {
        Kilometer(1000 * 1000),
        Meter(1000),
        Centimeter(10),
        Millimeter(1),
        Inch(25.4),
        Foot(25.4 * 12),
        Mile(25.4 * 12 * 5280);

        final double factor;

        Units(double factor) {
            this.factor = factor;
        }
    }

    private final JFrame frame;

    private final JFormattedTextField fromValueField;
    private final JFormattedTextField toValueField;

    private final JComboBox<Units> fromUnitsList;
    private final JComboBox<Units> toUnitsList;

    public UnitConverter() {
        fromValueField = new JFormattedTextField(
            new NumberFormatter(NumberFormat.getInstance()));
        toValueField = new JFormattedTextField(
            new NumberFormatter(NumberFormat.getInstance()));

        fromValueField.setColumns(5);
        toValueField.setColumns(5);

        fromUnitsList = new JComboBox<>(Units.values());
        toUnitsList = new JComboBox<>(Units.values());

        JButton convertButton = new JButton("Convert");

        frame = new JFrame("Unit Converter");
        frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);

        // Assemble window

        JPanel valuesPanel = new JPanel();
        valuesPanel.add(fromValueField);
        valuesPanel.add(fromUnitsList);
        valuesPanel.add(toValueField);
        valuesPanel.add(toUnitsList);

        frame.getContentPane().add(valuesPanel, BorderLayout.NORTH);
        frame.getContentPane().add(convertButton, BorderLayout.SOUTH);

        // Done assembling window

        frame.pack();
        frame.setLocationByPlatform(true);
    }

    public void show() {
        frame.setVisible(true);
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        EventQueue.invokeLater(() -> new UnitConverter().show());
    }
}

Notice the use of new JPanel(). This creates a JPanel with a FlowLayout as its layout manager. We know this because the documentation for that zero-argument JPanel constructor says so.

If you’re wondering why BorderLayout.NORTH and BorderLayout.SOUTH are used, the documentation for JFrame says:

The default content pane will have a BorderLayout manager set on it.

The above code is not perfect: if one resizes the window, the convert button expands, but the other fields do not. Other layout managers give you more options.

You can create two horizontal Boxes instead:

// Assemble window

// Allow button to resize.
convertButton.setMaximumSize(
    new Dimension(Integer.MAX_VALUE, Integer.MAX_VALUE));

Box buttonPanel = Box.createHorizontalBox();
buttonPanel.add(convertButton);
buttonPanel.setBorder(BorderFactory.createEmptyBorder(0, 6, 6, 6));

Box valuesPanel = Box.createHorizontalBox();
valuesPanel.add(fromValueField);
valuesPanel.add(fromUnitsList);
valuesPanel.add(Box.createHorizontalStrut(12));
valuesPanel.add(toValueField);
valuesPanel.add(toUnitsList);
valuesPanel.setBorder(BorderFactory.createEmptyBorder(6, 6, 6, 6));

frame.getContentPane().add(valuesPanel, BorderLayout.NORTH);
frame.getContentPane().add(buttonPanel, BorderLayout.SOUTH);

// Done assembling window

(A Box always uses a BoxLayout for its layout manager.)

GridBagLayout is the heavy duty solution. It is by far the most powerful layout in Java SE, but it is hard to learn. Even a relatively simple layout case like this one can be daunting:

// Assemble window

JPanel panel = new JPanel(new GridBagLayout());
GridBagConstraints gbc = new GridBagConstraints();
gbc.fill = GridBagConstraints.HORIZONTAL;
gbc.anchor = GridBagConstraints.BASELINE_LEADING;
gbc.weightx = 1;
panel.add(fromValueField, gbc);
gbc.weightx = 0;
panel.add(fromUnitsList, gbc);
gbc.weightx = 1;
gbc.insets.left = 12;
panel.add(toValueField, gbc);
gbc.weightx = 0;
gbc.insets.left = 0;
// Tell GridBagLayout this is the last component on the current row.
gbc.gridwidth = GridBagConstraints.REMAINDER;
panel.add(toUnitsList, gbc);

gbc.insets.top = 6;
gbc.weightx = 1;
panel.add(convertButton, gbc);

panel.setBorder(BorderFactory.createEmptyBorder(6, 6, 6, 6));

frame.getContentPane().add(panel);

// Done assembling window

Setting weightx to a nonzero value causes the corresponding component's cell to grow when the window grows.

It seems you see the value in using layout managers. BorderLayout will almost get you there but it won't handle spacing between the edge of the window and the host container which is why I set an empty border on it.

GroupLayout will get you all the way there without relying on a border but its learning curve is very steep

import java.awt.BorderLayout;
import javax.swing.JButton;
import javax.swing.JFrame;
import javax.swing.JPanel;
import javax.swing.WindowConstants;
import javax.swing.border.EmptyBorder;

final class Test {

    private Test() {
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        var button = new JButton("Convert");

        var frame = new JFrame("Unit Converter");
        frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(WindowConstants.DISPOSE_ON_CLOSE);

        var pane = (JPanel) frame.getContentPane();

        pane.setBorder(new EmptyBorder(5, 5, 5, 5));
        pane.add(button, BorderLayout.SOUTH);

        frame.setSize(500, 250);
        frame.setLocationRelativeTo(null);
        frame.setVisible(true);
    }
}

question_comments.body: Well, your question is about the button, but the image show multiple components. The position all the components in the image you can use the GridBagLayout. Read the section from the Swing tutorial on How to Use GridBagLayout for more information and examples. If you are truly only concerned about the button then use a BorderLayout and add the button to the BorderLayout. PAGE_END. The tutorial also has a section on the BorderLayout. Read up about all the layout managers.
Have you seen miglayout? It drastically simplifies swing layouts
For that I suppose you could just set the width of the button to the width of the container.
but I want it to look like this ^ (edited the post with the picture)
Use a FlowLayout and set it to CENTER.

79563303.body: This would be a better answer if you explained what you changed, and why.  Code-only answers usually are not useful.  We want people to learn to be better programmers, not to blindly copy things off the Internet.

79562852.body: @jamesdiaz, Yours is by no means a "more complex" UI. I already described in brief terms how BoxLayout could be used to satisfy your layout objectives, but you may not be appreciating a key detail: I have suggested nesting one container (a Box) inside another (I suggested a Box, but the frame's default content pane might be better). In this way, you can use a BoxLayout for the content pane to stack the Box and the "Convert" button vertically, and the nested Box's own, separate BoxLayout to stack the two dropdowns horizontally. Nesting containers is a powerful layout technique.

Thanks for the explanation! I’m an absolute beginner with Java and trying to understand how layout managers work. I looked into BoxLayout, but doesn’t it just stack everything vertically or horizontally?That seems hard to control visually, especially for more complex UIs. And with BorderLayout, since each region takes up a large portion of the frame, isn’t it difficult to get nicely balanced proportions or to position multiple components close together? Also, why exactly do I need to add components to the content pane instead of directly to the frame? What’s the technical reason behind that?
